title: Can two minds exist in one brain? - Quora

response.answer_text: I know that different states of consciousness can be expressed in the same brain, states that are not necessarily aware of the other states.  For example, in dreaming, I have no awareness of the memories or identity that I carry when I'm awake. When I am awake, I often have serious difficulty recalling my dream experience, so the disconnect between dream life from waking life could be a basis for seeing for multiple minds in one brain. I use the word multiple because the dream states are not coherent with each other, but separate constructions.  Then there is the layering of consciousness, where modes of mental functionality are separated by lack of memory recall and they work semi-autonomously.  People who have experienced serious trauma often repress whatever associations remind them of the trauma, and wall that off area of the mind.  That walled off area will sometimes take over and cause such a person to behave inappropriately in some situation because it resembles something from the trauma time. For example, someone who has been in wartime combat may dive for cover at the sound of a backfiring vehicle, or some other trigger stimulus may induce the person to start fighting. Multiple personality disorder can be seen as several minds in one brain also, but all of these examples are really examples of the fracturing of consciousness, breaks in the internal communications of a single mind in a single brain, either as a defense mechanism or as the product of an organic illness affecting brain function. That leaves the myth of demonic possession, which in my opinion is something that came about as an explanation for the existence of consciousness-fracturing mental illnesses that earlier generations of people could explain in no better way. As far as I am aware, it is one mind per brain, but minds can separate memories and functions into separate areas with little communication and this can take on the appearance of two or more minds per brain.  I will add that this compartmentalization is also normal, enabling awareness to concentrate on the most important issues at hand or as dreaming. When it becomes extreme, whether from organic disease or very high stress, it takes on pathological properties.

Happened to me once. Was watching a movie, the movie started to turn into a ““first person view” type movie. Suddenly, the movie characters mind (let’s call him bob) was mine. I’m sitting there staring at my screen completely convinced that I was thinking in this characters point of view while at the same time I’m thinking in my physical body. When I opened my mouth to speak, the character in the movie spoke what I wanted to say. What I wanted to think, Bob would think, but Bob’s mind was in mine. Or was I in his? Anyways, meanwhile, in my physical body’s mind I was slowly freaking out, I was worried I was going to be stuck in that state. So now, in my mind, I’m thinking what I wanted to think from Bob’s mind while also thinking in MY mind “what is going on? Will this end? Am I stuck in this state?” Both of these things were happening at the same time and it was slightly disorienting. It’s difficult to describe what two thinking minds in one brain feels like. So I started thinking about my family, and things that I’m convinced is part my life to sort of “ground” myself. It ended as quickly as it happened. Completely shook my understanding of how the mind works. extra: so while this is all occurring, there was this feeling in my mind that was telling me I needed to pick a mind. The one I DIDNT choose would completely go crazy and the one I chose would be mine. Obviously fear and the things that “ground” me made me pick mine.

Think about a terminal server, with various operative OS. You can consider the brain as a kind of computer, with nodes, cables, connections and electrical signals. Within this physical construction some kind of “windows like” software allows you to run different programs to organise your vital functions and interact with your organs, the external devices.. However to make the system more robust the inner algoritms created a kind of terminal server so the apps can run within different environments enbodied in the general main process. The way the software interacts with the external devices, will so change according the type of operative system you are using. Those systems may change according the houre of the day, the external cirumstances or other shadowed causes. Usually those operative systems are not impermable to each other, as they share common ressources as memories and paterns within the main server. However under some circumstances those ressources are simply locked by the server and so each terminal operative system will run the different softwares in a kind of safety mode using on top of it different sets of privat operative "virtual" devices. So if you consider mind not as the server but more as the terminals within, yes the brain can run different operative systems, but not in parallel.

The answer depends on your definition of "mind"  For example, schizophrenics seem to do a good job of having multiple minds in one brain, but that may not be the answer you're looking for. In that case, I'd say no. Each part of the brain contributes to an individual's understanding of the world through the sensory input it processes. This understanding is wound up in networks configured by synaptic weights of synapses between neurons. A "different mind," given that there's only one brain, would have to run on top of the same networks, meaning its experiences, conceptions, and memories would be exactly the same as the other mind. Maybe you're okay with that for your definition of mind, but that is enough to convince me otherwise.

It is difficult to know. I am not a doctor, but there is a computational theory of the "I" that interprets it as a fixed point in a space of prediction functions: Robot's and Human's self: a computational perspective. Although this paper mentions that it is very likely that this fixed point emerges, the truth is that the functions are not continuous, so there is no guarantee that the "I" is formed. On the other hand, like any fixed point, nothing prevents that there are several, which would build several "I" at the same time.
